Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery type A cup; interior glazed; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting perhaps of maenad and satyr facing left and part of handle palmette; at left, undetermined motif, followed by female with added red skirt with decorated hem and faded added white on feet; to right, legs of male and part of handle palmette; between them a red curving line, either the tail of a satyr or a line circumscribing the palmette; below, single streaky brown band, than a glazed area punctuated by a reserved band.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Beazley, J. D., Paralipomena. Oxford 1971, 81, no. 26, attributes the sherd to the FP Class.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0613) (Phase 1)
Beazley 1971 / Paralipomena, Additions to Attic Black-Figure Vase-Painters and to Attic Red-Figure Vase-Painters (81, 26)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
